riddle: I am seen in the water if seen in the sky. I am in the rainbow, a jay’s feather,and lapis lazuli.
Lighter than what I am made of, more of me is hidden than is seen.
Until I am measured, I am not known, yet how you miss me, when I have flown.
You throw away the outside and cook the inside. Then you eat the outside and throw away the inside. What did you eat?

A mile from end to end, yet as close to as a friend. A precious commodity, freely given. Seen on the dead and on the living. Found on the rich, poor, short and tall, but shared among children most of all. What is it?
What question can you never honestly answer yes to?
You have to travel far before you turn it over. What is it?
I can be long, or I can be short, I can be grown, and I can be bought, I can be painted, or left bare, I can be round, or square. What am I?
You heard me before, yet you hear me again, then I die, ’till you call me again.
A box without hinges, lock or key, yet golden treasure lies within. What is it?
I am a word of 5 letters and people eat me. If you remove the first letter I become a form of energy. Remove the first two and I’m needed to live. Scramble the last 3 and you can drink me. What am I?
Until I am measured, I am not known, yet how you miss me, when I have flown.
I give you a group of three. One is sitting down, and will never get up. The second eats as much as is given to him, yet is always hungry. The third goes away and never returns.
What is in seasons, seconds, centuries and minutes but not in decades, years or days?

This is a most unusual paragraph. How quickly can you find out what is so unusual about it? It looks so ordinary, you’d think nothing was wrong with it – and in fact, nothing is wrong with it. It is unusual though. Why? Study it, think about it, and you may find out. Try to do it without coaching. If you work at it for a bit it will dawn on you. So jump to it and try your skill at figuring it out. Good luck – don’t blow your cool!

Five hundred begins it, five hundred ends it, five in the middle is seen; First of all figures, the first of all letters, take up their stations between. Join all together, and then you will bring before you the name of an eminent king.
All about, but cannot be seen, can be captured, cannot be held, no throat, but can be heard.
I am a word of 5 letters and people eat me. If you remove the first letter I become a form of energy. Remove the first two and I’m needed to live. Scramble the last 3 and you can drink me. What am I?
An iron horse with a flaxen tail. The faster the horse runs, the shorter his tail becomes. What is it?
A woman shoots her husband, then holds him under water for five minutes. Finally, she hangs him. Five minutes later they enjoy a wonderful dinner together. How can this be?
What happens when you throw a yellow rock into a purple stream?
Kings and lords and christians raised them, since they stand for higher powers, yet few of them would stand, I’m certain, if men ruled this world of ours.
All about, but cannot be seen, can be captured, cannot be held, no throat, but can be heard.
A box without hinges, lock or key, yet golden treasure lies within. What is it?
Forward I’m heavy, but backwards I’m not. What am I?
An iron horse with a flaxen tail. The faster the horse runs, the shorter his tail becomes. What is it?
What is in seasons, seconds, centuries and minutes but not in decades, years or days?
Feed me and I live, give me drink and I die. What am I?

I am, in truth, a yellow fork from tables in the sky, by inadvertent fingers dropped the awful cutlery, of mansions never quite disclosed and never quite concealed. The apparatus of the dark to ignorance revealed.
I am a box that holds keys without locks, yet they can unlock your soul. What am I?

What does man love more than life, fear more than death or mortal strife? What the poor have, the rich require, and what contented men desire, what the miser spends and the spendthrift saves, and all men carry to their graves?
Alive without breath, as cold as death. Clad in mail never clinking, never thirsty, ever drinking. What am I?
You heard me before, yet you hear me again, then I die, ’till you call me again.
What’s black when you get it, red when you use it, and white when you’re all through with it?
Die without me, never thank me. Walk right through me, never feel me. Always watching, never speaking. Always lurking, never seen.
I live in water. If you cut my head I’m at your door, if you cut my tail I’m fruit, if you cut both I’m with you. What am I?
Forward I’m heavy, but backwards I’m not. What am I?
Until I am measured, I am not known, yet how you miss me, when I have flown.
Until I am measured I am not known, yet how you miss me when I have flown. What am I?

There once was a strange man who loved wordplay, he had a very important and successful business that would take insect shipments from all across the world and distribute them to zoos across the US. Whats his company name?
You saw me where I never was and where I could not be. And yet within that very place, my face you often see. What am I?

Four of us are in your field, but our differences keep us at yield. First, a one that is no fool, though he resembles a gardener’s tool. Next, one difficult to split in two, and a girl once had one as big as her shoe. Then, to the mind, one’s a lovely bonder, and truancy makes it grow fonder. Last, a stem connecting dots of three. Knowing all this, what are we?
It cannot be seen, it weighs nothing, but when put into a barrel, it makes it lighter. What is it?
Pregnant every time you see her, yet she never will give birth.

Three brothers share a family sport: A non-stop marathon. The oldest one is fat and short And trudges slowly on the middle brother’s tall and slim and keeps a steady pace. The youngest runs just like the wind, a speeding through the race. Hes young in years, we let him run, the other brothers say Cause though he’s surely number one, he’s second, in a way.
How do you make 30 cents with two coins if one of them is not a quarter?
With thieves I consort. With the vilest, in short, I’m quite at ease in depravity; Yet all divines use me, and savants can’t lose me, for I am the center of gravity.
Reaching stiffly for the sky, I bare my fingers when it’s cold. In warmth I wear an emerald glove and in between I dress in gold
Until I am measured, I am not known, yet how you miss me, when I have flown.
If you break me, I do not stop working. If you touch me, I may be snared. If you lose me, nothing will matter. What am I?
I can be long, or I can be short, I can be grown, and I can be bought, I can be painted, or left bare, I can be round, or square. What am I?
Alive without breath, as cold as death. Clad in mail never clinking, never thirsty, ever drinking. What am I?

The youngest runs just like the wind, a speeding through the race. Hes young in years, we let him run, the other brothers say Cause though he’s surely number one, he’s second, in a way.
I am the beginning of the end, and the end of time and space. I am essential to creation, and I surround every place. What am I?
When set loose, I fly away, never so cursed, as when I go astray.
This thing all things devours: Birds, beasts, trees, flowers. Gnaws iron, bites steel; Grinds hard stones to meal; Slays king, ruins town, and beats high mountain down.
A man went to the hardware store to buy items for his house. 1 would cost $.25. 12 would cost $.50. 122 would cost $.75. When he left the store he had spent $.75, what did he buy?

Knowing all this, what are we?
Say my name and I disappear. What am I?

I am a word of meanings three. Three ways of spelling me there be. The first is an odour, a smell if you will. The second some money, but not in a bill. The third is past tense, a method of passing things on or around. Can you tell me now, what these words are, that have the same sound?
Kings and queens may cling to power and the jester’s got his call, but, as you may all discover, the common one outranks them all.
At the sound of me, men may dream or stamp their feet. At the sound of me, women may laugh or sometimes weep.
I am a box that holds keys without locks, yet they can unlock your soul. What am I?
What gets wetter as it dries?

There is one word that stands the test of time and holds fast to the center of everything. Though everyone will try at least once in their life to move around this word, but in fact, unknowingly, they use it every moment of the day. Young or old, awake or in sleep, human or animal, this word stands fast. It belongs to everyone, to all living things, but no one can master it. The word is?
A box without hinges, lock or key, yet golden treasure lies within. What is it?
What English word has three consecutive double letters?
One by one we fall from heaven down into the depths of past, and our world is ever upturned so that yet some time we’ll last.
It is greater than God and more evil than the devil. The poor have it, the rich need it and if you eat it you’ll die. What is it?

I drift forever with the current down these long canals they’ve made, tame, yet wild, I run elusive Multitasking to your aid. Before I came, the world was darker, colder, sometimes, rougher, true, but though I might make living easy, I’m good at killing people too.

My days are in the summer. When you’ll eat me when I’m hot. In fact I’ll even eat myself where battles tough are fought, but when you find me in a fight, ‘twill be high in the sky, and if you catch me napping, I suggest you let me lie. When you’re bad, come to my house, from Ma get thoughts profound. Am I big or am I small? Some say I’m just a pound.

The more you take, the more you leave behind. What am I?
I never was, am always to be. No one ever saw me, nor ever will, and yet I am the confidence of all to live and breathe on this terrestrial ball.

Five hundred begins it, five hundred ends it, five in the middle is seen; First of all figures, the first of all letters, take up their stations between. Join all together, and then you will bring before you the name of an eminent king.
Soft and fragile is my skin, I get my growth in mud. I’m dangerous as much as pretty, for if not careful, I draw blood.

I am a word of 5 letters and people eat me. If you remove the first letter I become a form of energy. Remove the first two and I’m needed to live. Scramble the last 3 and you can drink me. What am I?
Each morning I appear to lie at your feet, all day I will follow no matter how fast you run, yet I nearly perish in the midday sun.
I’m full of holes, yet I’m full of water. What am I?
When you went into the woods you got me. You hated me yet you wanted to find me. You went home with me cause you couldn’t find me. What was it?

What question can you never honestly answer yes to?
I drive men mad for love of me, easily beaten, never free. What am I?

A mile from end to end, yet as close to as a friend. A precious commodity, freely given. Seen on the dead and on the living. Found on the rich, poor, short and tall, but shared among children most of all. What is it?

My days are in the summer. When you’ll eat me when I’m hot. In fact I’ll even eat myself where battles tough are fought, but when you find me in a fight, ‘twill be high in the sky, and if you catch me napping, I suggest you let me lie. When you’re bad, come to my house, from Ma get thoughts profound. Am I big or am I small? Some say I’m just a pound.
You have to travel far before you turn it over. What is it?
Feed me and I live, give me drink and I die. What am I?

At night they come without being fetched. By day they are lost without being stolen. What are they?
I live in water. If you cut my head I’m at your door, if you cut my tail I’m fruit, if you cut both I’m with you. What am I?

Four of us are in your field, but our differences keep us at yield. First, a one that is no fool, though he resembles a gardener’s tool. Next, one difficult to split in two, and a girl once had one as big as her shoe. Then, to the mind, one’s a lovely bonder, and truancy makes it grow fonder. Last, a stem connecting dots of three. Knowing all this, what are we?
I am the beginning of the end, and the end of time and space. I am essential to creation, and I surround every place. What am I?
I go around in circles, but always straight ahead. Never complain, no matter where I am led.

Three brothers share a family sport: A non-stop marathon. The oldest one is fat and short And trudges slowly on the middle brother’s tall and slim and keeps a steady pace. The youngest runs just like the wind, a speeding through the race. Hes young in years, we let him run, the other brothers say Cause though he’s surely number one, he’s second, in a way.
I go around in circles, but always straight ahead. Never complain, no matter where I am led.

I am a word of meanings three. Three ways of spelling me there be. The first is an odour, a smell if you will. The second some money, but not in a bill. The third is past tense, a method of passing things on or around. Can you tell me now, what these words are, that have the same sound?

There is one word that stands the test of time and holds fast to the center of everything. Though everyone will try at least once in their life to move around this word, but in fact, unknowingly, they use it every moment of the day. My first is twice in apple but not once in tart. My second is in liver but not in heart. My third is in giant and also in ghost. Whole I’m best when I am roast. What am I?

Before any changes I’m a garlic or spice. My first is altered and I’m a hand-warming device. My second is changed and I’m trees in full bloom. The next letter change makes a deathly old tomb. Change the fourth to make a fruit of the vine. Change the last for a chart plotted with lines. What was I? What did I become? What did I turn out to be?

It is unusual though. Why? Study it, think about it, and you may find out. Try to do it without coaching. If you work at it for a bit it will dawn on you. So jump to it and try your skill at figuring it out. Good luck – don’t blow your cool!
I am a word of 5 letters and people eat me. If you remove the first letter I become a form of energy. Remove the first two and I’m needed to live. Scramble the last 3 and you can drink me. What am I?
The cost of making only the maker knows, valueless if bought, but sometimes traded. A poor man may give one as easily as a king. When one is broken pain and deceit are assured. What is it?
When young, I am sweet in the sun. When middle-aged, I make you happy. When old, I am valued more than ever.
You heard me before, yet you hear me again, then I die, ’till you call me again.
When set loose, I fly away, never so cursed, as when I go astray.
It walks on four legs in the morning, two legs at noon and three legs in the evening. What is it?

Five hundred begins it, five hundred ends it, five in the middle is seen; First of all figures, the first of all letters, take up their stations between. Join all together, and then you will bring before you the name of an eminent king.
As I went over London Bridge I met my sister Jenny, I broke her neck and drank her blood and left her standing empty.
Glittering points that downward thrust, sparkling spears that never rust. What am I?

My days are in the summer. When you’ll eat me when I’m hot. In fact I’ll even eat myself where battles tough are fought, but when you find me in a fight, ‘twill be high in the sky, and if you catch me napping, I suggest you let me lie. When you’re bad, come to my house, from Ma get thoughts profound. Am I big or am I small? Some say I’m just a pound.
I am seen in the water if seen in the sky. I am in the rainbow, a jay’s feather,and lapis lazuli.
I am always hungry, I must always be fed, the finger I touch, will soon turn red. What am I?
Glittering points that downward thrust, sparkling spears that never rust.
I drive men mad for love of me, easily beaten, never free. What am I?
I never was, am always to be. No one ever saw me, nor ever will, and yet I am the confidence of all to live and breathe on this terrestrial ball.
What is in seasons, seconds, centuries and minutes but not in decades, years or days?

Before any changes I’m a garlic or spice. My first is altered and I’m a hand-warming device. My second is changed and I’m trees in full bloom. The next letter change makes a deathly old tomb. Change the fourth to make a fruit of the vine. Change the last for a chart plotted with lines. What was I? What did I become? What did I turn out to be?
My life can be measured in hours, I serve by being devoured. Thin, I am quick. Fat, I am slow. Wind is my foe.
What makes a loud noise when changing its jacket, becomes larger but weighs less?

This is a most unusual paragraph. How quickly can you find out what is so unusual about it? It looks so ordinary, you’d think nothing was wrong with it – and in fact, nothing is wrong with it. It is unusual though. Why? Study it, think about it, and you may find out. Try to do it without coaching. If you work at it for a bit it will dawn on you. So jump to it and try your skill at figuring it out. Good luck – don’t blow your cool!
Feed me and I live, give me drink and I die. What am I?
Who makes it, has no need of it. Who buys it, has no use for it. Who uses it can neither see nor feel it.
It’s red, blue, purple and green, no one can reach it, not even the queen. What is it?
The cost of making only the maker knows, valueless if bought, but sometimes traded. A poor man may give one as easily as a king. When one is broken pain and deceit are assured. What is it?
Alive without breath, as cold as death. Clad in mail never clinking, never thirsty, ever drinking. What am I?
Whoever makes it, tells it not. Whoever takes it, knows it not. Whoever knows it, wants it not.

Every dawn begins with me, at dusk I’ll be the first you see, and daybreak couldn’t come without what midday centers all about. Daises grow from me, I’m told. And when I come, I end all cold, but in the sun I won’t be found, yet still, each day I’ll be around.
As I went over London Bridge I met my sister Jenny, I broke her neck and drank her blood and left her standing empty.
You throw away the outside and cook the inside. Then you eat the outside and throw away the inside. What did you eat?
What question can you never honestly answer yes to?
Kings and lords and christians raised them, since they stand for higher powers, yet few of them would stand, I’m certain, if men ruled this world of ours.
Until I am measured I am not known, yet how you miss me when I have flown. What am I?
Alive without breath, as cold as death. Never thirsty, ever drinking. Clad in mail, never clinking. Drowns on dry land, thinks an island is a mountain. Thinks a fountain, is a puff of air.
The more you have of it, the less you see. What is it?
With thieves I consort. With the vilest, in short, I’m quite at ease in depravity; Yet all divines use me, and savants can’t lose me, for I am the center of gravity.
When you went into the woods you got me. You hated me yet you wanted to find me. You went home with me cause you couldn’t find me. What was it?
When young, I am sweet in the sun. When middle-aged, I make you happy. When old, I am valued more than ever.
I know a word of letters three. Add two, and fewer there will be!
I can be long, or I can be short, I can be grown, and I can be bought, I can be painted, or left bare, I can be round, or square. What am I?
Three lives have I. Gentle enough to soothe the skin, light enough to caress the sky, hard enough to crack rocks.
It is greater than God and more evil than the devil. The poor have it, the rich need it and if you eat it you’ll die. What is it?

There is one word that stands the test of time and holds fast to the center of everything. Though everyone will try at least once in their life to move around this word, but in fact, unknowingly, they use it every moment of the day. Young or old, awake or in sleep, human or animal, this word stands fast. It belongs to everyone, to all living things, but no one can master it. The word is?

Three brothers share a family sport: A non-stop marathon. The oldest one is fat and short And trudges slowly on the middle brother’s tall and slim and keeps a steady pace. The youngest runs just like the wind, a speeding through the race. Hes young in years, we let him run, the other brothers say Cause though he’s surely number one, he’s second, in a way.
What begins and has no end? What is the ending of all that begins?
It cannot be seen, it weighs nothing, but when put into a barrel, it makes it lighter. What is it?
Who makes it, has no need of it. Who buys it, has no use for it. Who uses it can neither see nor feel it.

What does man love more than life, fear more than death or mortal strife? What the poor have, the rich require, and what contented men desire, what the miser spends and the spendthrift saves, and all men carry to their graves?

Four of us are in your field, but our differences keep us at yield. First, a one that is no fool, though he resembles a gardener’s tool. Next, one difficult to split in two, and a girl once had one as big as her shoe. Then, to the mind, one’s a lovely bonder, and truancy makes it grow fonder. Last, a stem connecting dots of three. Knowing all this, what are we?
Alive without breath, as cold as death. Clad in mail never clinking, never thirsty, ever drinking. What am I?
